In my ongoing saga of merging in a proof that the density of squarefree integers is Î¶(2)â»Â¹, I was wondering about the best way to approach the formal_multilinear_series API. In particular, I wanted to formalize the fact that a uniform limit of holomorphic functions is holomorphic in a different way than #13500.

Specifically, let fn:Câ†’Cf_n : \mathbb{C} â†’ \mathbb{C}fnâ€‹:Câ†’C be a sequence of functions which are analytic on the disk of radius r>0r > 0r>0 centered at 000 and which converge uniformly to some fff on that disk. Then fn(z)=âˆ‘anizi/i!f_n (z) = \sum a_{ni} z^i / i!fnâ€‹(z)=âˆ‘aniâ€‹zi/i! for some aniâˆˆCa_{ni} \in \mathbb{C}aniâ€‹âˆˆC and all âˆ£zâˆ£<r|z| < râˆ£zâˆ£<r. Let fnM(z)=âˆ‘i=0Manizi/i!f_n^M(z) = \sum_{i=0}^M a_{ni} z^i / i!fnMâ€‹(z)=âˆ‘i=0Mâ€‹aniâ€‹zi/i! be the partial sums.

Define Fn(z)=âˆ‘anizi+1/(i+1)!F_n (z) = \sum a_{ni} z^{i+1} / (i + 1)!Fnâ€‹(z)=âˆ‘aniâ€‹zi+1/(i+1)! and FnMF_n^MFnMâ€‹ the partial sums. By the fundamental theorem of calculus and linearity of integration, for all âˆ£zâˆ£<r|z| < râˆ£zâˆ£<r we have FnM(z)=zâˆ«01fnM(tz)dtF_n^M(z) = z\int_0^1 f_n^M(tz)dtFnMâ€‹(z)=zâˆ«01â€‹fnMâ€‹(tz)dt.

With these definitions in hand, you can apply #14090, dominated convergence, and the fact that the partial sums of power series converge uniformly on all closed balls within their radius of convergence several times to show that the FnMF_n^MFnMâ€‹ converge (necessarily to FnF_nFnâ€‹), the FnF_nFnâ€‹ converge to some FFF, thus Fâ€²=fF' = fFâ€²=f and so fff is holomorphic.

My difficulty is that I'm finding the formal_multilinear_series API to be very difficult to grok. I was curious if someone could give me a hint toward defining the partial sums FnMF_n^MFnMâ€‹ above?
Does looking at the definition of src#exp and src#exp_series help at all?
Once you've managed to construct the series object, the partial sums should be docs#formal_multilinear_series.partial_sum

I am having a similar experience trying to prove the isolated zeros theorem for analytic functions, that manipulating formal_multilinear_series explicitly (in my case, to extract a (z-z0)^n factor) is a little painful. src#exp_series is nice, but as far as I can tell the series provided from analytic_at for a function from C to C is not of that form so it does not really help...

formal_multilinear_series is specifically designed for functions of several variables. For functions of one variable, one should definitely build a simplified and easier to use API, in the same way that we have fderiv for the general FrÃ©chet derivative, and deriv for the more specific one-dimensional version.
I don't agree that it's for multiple variables, things like docs#formal_multilinear_series.sum are in terms of a single variable
Oh, I guess your point is that using multilinear maps internally is overkill for a ring?
Yes but your Â«Â single variableÂ Â» lives in a vector space over K, not in K, so it is indeed multivariable calculus

Yes, using multilinear maps over a ring or a field is definitely overkill: you just have one coefficient, so instead of writing p_n (x, ..., x), you should just use a_n x^n. Of course, we should keep the definition of analytic_at (in the same way that differentiable_at is always expressed in terms of fderiv, whether in one or higher dimension), but we should be able to construct a function from a list of coefficients instead of a list of multilinear maps, for instance.

Indeed I can imagine this to be a bit painful. The following should help you (maybe some of it is already in mathlib, feel free to PR the rest if you need it).

import analysis.analytic.basic
import ring_theory.power_series.basic

open_locale big_operators

variables {Î¹ ğ•œ E F : Type*} [fintype Î¹] [decidable_eq Î¹]

lemma fooâ‚ [comm_semiring ğ•œ] [add_comm_monoid E] [module ğ•œ E] (f : multilinear_map ğ•œ (Î» i : Î¹, ğ•œ) E)
  (x : Î¹ â†’ ğ•œ) : f x = (âˆ i, x i) â€¢ (f 1) :=
begin
  rw â† multilinear_map.map_smul_univ,
  exact congr_arg f (funext $ Î» i, by simp)
end

lemma fooâ‚‚ [comm_semiring ğ•œ] (f : multilinear_map ğ•œ (Î» i : Î¹, ğ•œ) ğ•œ)
  (x : Î¹ â†’ ğ•œ) : f x = (f 1) * (âˆ i, x i) :=
by rw [fooâ‚, smul_eq_mul, mul_comm]

lemma barâ‚ [comm_semiring ğ•œ] [add_comm_monoid E] [module ğ•œ E]
  [topological_space ğ•œ] [topological_space E]
  (f : continuous_multilinear_map ğ•œ (Î» i : Î¹, ğ•œ) E)
  (x : Î¹ â†’ ğ•œ) : f x = (âˆ i, x i) â€¢ (f 1) :=
fooâ‚ f.to_multilinear_map x

lemma barâ‚‚ [comm_semiring ğ•œ] [topological_space ğ•œ]
  (f : continuous_multilinear_map ğ•œ (Î» i : Î¹, ğ•œ) ğ•œ)
  (x : Î¹ â†’ ğ•œ) : f x = (f 1) * (âˆ i, x i) :=
fooâ‚‚ f.to_multilinear_map x

lemma sumâ‚ [comm_ring ğ•œ] [add_comm_group E] [module ğ•œ E]
  [topological_space ğ•œ] [topological_add_group ğ•œ] [has_continuous_const_smul ğ•œ ğ•œ]
  [topological_space E] [topological_add_group E] [has_continuous_const_smul ğ•œ E]
  (Ï† : formal_multilinear_series ğ•œ ğ•œ E) (x : ğ•œ) :
  Ï†.sum x = âˆ‘' (n : â„•), x^n â€¢ (Ï† n 1) :=
begin
  rw formal_multilinear_series.sum,
  congr,
  ext n,
  rw [barâ‚, fin.prod_const]
end

  [topological_space ğ•œ] [topological_add_group ğ•œ] [has_continuous_const_smul ğ•œ ğ•œ]
  (Ï† : formal_multilinear_series ğ•œ ğ•œ ğ•œ) (x : ğ•œ) :
  Ï†.sum x = âˆ‘' (n : â„•), (Ï† n 1) * x^n :=
begin
  rw formal_multilinear_series.sum,
  congr,
  ext n,
  rw [barâ‚‚, fin.prod_const]
end

lemma partial_sumâ‚ [comm_ring ğ•œ] [add_comm_group E] [module ğ•œ E]
  [topological_space ğ•œ] [topological_add_group ğ•œ] [has_continuous_const_smul ğ•œ ğ•œ]
  [topological_space E] [topological_add_group E] [has_continuous_const_smul ğ•œ E]
  (Ï† : formal_multilinear_series ğ•œ ğ•œ E) (x : ğ•œ) (n : â„•) :
  Ï†.partial_sum n x = âˆ‘ k in finset.range n, x^k â€¢ (Ï† k 1) :=
begin
  rw formal_multilinear_series.partial_sum,

  ext n,

lemma partial_sumâ‚‚ [comm_ring ğ•œ]
  [topological_space ğ•œ] [topological_add_group ğ•œ] [has_continuous_const_smul ğ•œ ğ•œ]
  (Ï† : formal_multilinear_series ğ•œ ğ•œ ğ•œ) (x : ğ•œ) (n : â„•) :
  Ï†.partial_sum n x = âˆ‘ k in finset.range n, (Ï† k 1) * x^k :=
begin
  rw formal_multilinear_series.partial_sum,
  congr,
  ext n,

Nice! For the case of holomorphic functions, an alternative strategy is to use the Cauchy integral formula (like in the proof that holomorphic functions are analytic) and the fact that it is preserved under uniform limits:

lemma weierstrass_1 {Î¹ : Type*} {p : filter Î¹} [p.ne_bot] (hr : 0 < r) {F : Î¹ â†’ â„‚ â†’ â„‚}
  (F_cont : âˆ€ i, continuous_on (F i) (closed_ball c r))
  (F_holo : âˆ€ i, differentiable_on â„‚ (F i) (ball c r))
  (F_conv : tendsto_uniformly_on F f p (closed_ball c r)) :
  differentiable_on â„‚ f (ball c r) :=
begin
  let R := r.to_nnreal,

  have h1 : âˆ€ (i : Î¹) (w âˆˆ ball c r),
    (2 * â†‘real.pi * I)â»Â¹ â€¢ âˆ® z in C(c, r), (z - w)â»Â¹ â€¢ F i z = F i w,
    by { rintro n z hz,
      refine two_pi_I_inv_smul_circle_integral_sub_inv_smul_of_differentiable_on_off_countable
        countable_empty hz (F_cont n) (Î» x hx, _),
      rw diff_empty at hx,
      exact (F_holo n).differentiable_at (is_open_ball.mem_nhds hx) },
  have h2 : eq_on (Î» w, (2 * â†‘real.pi * I)â»Â¹ â€¢ âˆ® z in C(c, R), (z - w)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z) f
      (emetric.ball c R),
    by { rintro w hw,
      replace hw : w âˆˆ ball c r := by { rw â† emetric_ball; simpa [hr.le] using hw },
      have h := Î» n, h1 n w hw,
      suffices : tendsto (Î» n, (2 * â†‘real.pi * I)â»Â¹ â€¢ âˆ® z in C(c, r), (z - w)â»Â¹ â€¢ F n z)
        p (ğ“ ((2 * â†‘real.pi * I)â»Â¹ â€¢ âˆ® z in C(c, R), (z - w)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z)),
      from tendsto_nhds_unique this ((tendsto_congr h).mpr
        (F_conv.tendsto_at (ball_subset_closed_ball hw))),
      apply tendsto.const_smul,
      simp only [hr.le, real.coe_to_nnreal', max_eq_left],
      refine tendsto_uniformly_on.tendsto_circle_integral hr _ _,
      { intro n,
        refine continuous_on.smul _ ((F_cont n).mono sphere_subset_closed_ball),
        refine continuous_on.invâ‚€ (continuous_on_id.sub continuous_on_const) _,
        rintro z hz hzw,
        rw [â† sub_eq_zero.mp hzw] at hw,
        exact set.disjoint_iff.mp sphere_disjoint_ball âŸ¨hz, hwâŸ© },
      { rw [tendsto_uniformly_on_iff] at âŠ¢ F_conv,
        rintro Îµ hÎµ,
        simp only [mem_ball] at hw,
        have hh1 : Îµ * (r - dist w c) > 0 := (mul_pos hÎµ.lt (sub_pos.mpr hw)).gt,
        specialize F_conv (Îµ * (r - dist w c)) hh1,
        filter_upwards [F_conv] with n h z hz,
        specialize h z (sphere_subset_closed_ball hz),
        have hh2 : r - dist w c â‰¤ abs (z - w) :=
          by { simp only [mem_sphere_iff_norm, norm_eq_abs] at hz,
            simpa [hz, complex.dist_eq] using norm_sub_norm_le (z - c) (w - c) },
        rw [dist_smul],
        simp only [norm_eq_abs, complex.abs_inv],
        rw [inv_mul_lt_iff'],
        { apply lt_of_lt_of_le h,
          exact (mul_le_mul_left hÎµ.lt).mpr hh2 },
        { linarith } } },
  have h3 : has_fpower_series_on_ball f (cauchy_power_series f c R) c R,
    by { refine (has_fpower_series_on_cauchy_integral _ (by simpa)).congr h2,
      have := (F_conv.continuous_on (eventually_of_forall F_cont)).mono sphere_subset_closed_ball,
      exact continuous_on.circle_integrable (by simp) (by simpa [hr.le]) },
  convert â† h3.differentiable_on; exact emetric_ball
end

Kevin Wilson said:

And, sorry, When you say "that derivatives also converge locally uniformly," I don't quite grok what you mean
